Award.AwardTitle: FAIR Publishing Guidelines for Spectral Data and Chemical Structures in Support of Chemistry and Related Disciplinary Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the PIs will convene a meeting to establish publishing guidelines for sharing machine-readable files of commonly reported chemical data classes. The workshop organizers seek involvement from researchers, publishers, funding agencies, libraries, database and repository managers, tool developers, chemical societies, and standards organizations. Topics to discuss include formulating value propositions for data (that is, what data should be kept and for how long), and formulating criteria and stakeholder roles to better support data that are Findable, Accessible Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR). Several outcomes are expected, including best-practice publishing guidelines specifying FAIR criteria for spectral and chemical structure data; and workflow models for capturing, managing and sharing these data in domain repositories. This workshop will build on momentum from the Research Data Alliance (RDA), the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), the American Chemical Society (ACS) and other related scientific societies.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation?s Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal funded a workshop program related to enabling better practices for open dissemination of core chemistry data types in machine-readable form, including chemical structures and spectral data. Attendees included researchers, publishers, librarians, repositories, and other information professionals with active roles that impact the publishing and data environment in the field of chemistry. These diverse perspectives facilitated connection across complementary expertise in chemical information, and leveraged this expertise into a number of topical breakout discussions. The breakout discussions covered (1) criteria for ensuring data are findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable (FAIR); (2) scalable workflows for data sharing; and (3) opportunities and challenges for critical stakeholders. The meeting was focused on brainstorming practical strategies that were tractable within existing infrastructure and could be implemented in the near term. 

 

From these discussions, several practical outcomes were achieved such as drafting of guidance for researchers, which are openly available via the workshop project website (https://osf.io/psq7k/). An additional outcome includes value propositions for each stakeholder (e.g., researchers, publishers) that clearly enumerate the needs and merit for sharing chemical data that can be incorporated into author data sharing strategies and data publisher services. For example, American Chemical Society Publications, a prominent chemistry publisher, subsequently initiated a pilot for sharing machine-readable data associated with the publishing requirements of two journals based on the workflow brainstorm discussions at the workshop (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.orglett.0c00383). Conversations with chemistry publishers and the community are ongoing, and will include future publisher panels and symposia at chemistry meetings, specifically targeting conversations around advancing the dissemination of machine-readable chemical data. The outcomes from this workshop also influenced the recommendations for data sharing described in the ACS Guide to Scholarly Communication (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/book/10.1021/acsguide). 

 

Access to machine-readable chemical data helps scientists more easily reproduce reported results as well as gain new insights from the data that would not be possible with traditional static published data (i.e., a processed figure in a scientific article). More broadly, sharing machine-readable chemical data benefits the community greatly as data can be more easily incorporated into publicly accessible databases and information resources. 


For interested readers, all workshop notes are on the project website (https://osf.io/psq7k/)  and an evaluative summary of the workshop is available: https://doi.org/10.7298/fs2d-hx95.
